Do not alter a control variable in the body of a 'for' statement

Make sure to explain the goal, objective that a function achieves to improve its maintainability
Ensure your code does not have un-referenced functions as it may indicate missed functionality and impairs maintainability
Enrich your code with comments to give an overview of the code to improve maintainability
Ensure to keep your code maintainable by reducing the nested control statements

Prefer using AngularJS wrapper service $window to maintain structuredness of code

Ensure using {@code} to wrap code statements

Avoid using "continue" statement

Avoid using 'setjmp' or 'longjmp' (C/C++)
Ensure that Switch statements have at least 2 case clauses

Ensure to not use //, /* within comments

Ensure to use an integral value to iterate in loops

Avoid having  a method call or additional expressions in a statement using "++" or "--" operators (C/C++)

Ensure to use C++ style notation casts to avoid unexpected type conversions

Ensure that pointer types are not cast to integral types
Ensure that you use 'enum' types with  [ ], =, == and !=, the unary & operator, and <, <=, >, >=.
Avoid dynamic_cast to convert current object to its derived class from its constructor or destructor
Avoid using goto to jump backwards into a statement in the same function(C/C++)
Mke sure you do not have unused labels in your code
Avoid using typeid in polymorphic class from the body of its constructor or destructor.
Ensure that you have a limited number of paramenters in OR clauses or IN statements to ensure good query performance
Make sure to define Primary Key (PK) for your tables to enforce row integrity of data
Prefer not having table names using characters outside of [a-z,0-9,_] for better readability and changeability
Prefer not having view names using characters outside of [a-z,0-9,_] for better readability and changeability
Ensure to have your packages named based on the same naming convention for better readability
Ensure to have your package functions named based on the same naming convention for better readability
Ensure to have your package stored procedures named based on the same naming convention for better readability
Ensure that your tables do not have large number of columns as it tends to add redundancy in data, try dividing the tables instead and link them through keys
Ensure to use one SQL statement per line to enhance readability and maintainability of query statements
Ensure that you do not have triggers acting on other triggers and cascading, review your design to avoid such cases
Ensure your table aliases do not have numbers to improve readability

When using compound indexes, avoid having different index ordering in collection access
